Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: 3D Printing of Civil Infrastructure Materials with Controlled Microstructural Architectures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project is to use additive manufacturing (3D printing) to engineer the microstructure of cement-based materials and fabricate cement-based structures with otherwise unachievable, controlled local composition of the material and spatial arrangement of its components. The goal of the research is to understand the major factors controlling the 3D printing process of cement-based materials and how to design interfacial interactions between printed filament layers and between filament inclusions and solid matrix phases. Though the use of additive manufacturing, the proposed research project has the potential to enable significant progress in the fields of high-performance infrastructure materials by providing materials that exhibit paradigm-shifting properties allowing new functionalities that are not achievable with existing materials. Ultimately, the 3-D printing processes will enable the fabrication of light-weight and modular structures and buildings for rapid deployment in cases of natural disasters and product applications wherein cement-based materials have not previously been competitive. The educational component will leverage existing programs of each of the three institutions and includes the development of instructional materials for undergraduate and graduate students and research opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduate students.

The goal of this collaborative research is to fundamentally understand (1) the intertwined mechanisms between chemistry, printed filament layer solidification, and 3D printing successive-layering-deposition process conditions and (2) the interfacial interactions between printed layers that control the bonding mechanism. 3-D printing is anticipated to enable the controlled spatial variation of material properties through continuous gradients in functional components. Experimental investigations of the filament layer solidification process and of the interfacial characteristics will be integrated with computational analysis, including molecular dynamics simulations of the molecular scale structure, energetics, and mechanical properties of the inter-filament and interfaces to unravel the physico-chemo-mechanical mechanisms that underpin the processing/manufacturing-microstructure-property relationship of the architectured materials. The research will (1) provide a molecular to nanoscale picture of the chemo-mechanical interactions between filament layers and between the filament inclusions and matrix interfaces, (2) identify key aspects of the structure at interfaces necessary to enable refinement of surfaces and printing media chemistry, and (3) provide insights into the development of a new approach to understanding and developing cementitious systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive manufacturing (AM), also called 3D printing, involves the layer-by-layer build-up of material to form an object, whereas subtractive manufacturing is the layer-by-layer removal of materials to form an object.  In general, building layer-by-layer is less wasteful and provides greater design flexibility with respect to shapes that can be made.  As incredible as it seems, houses and even commercial multi-story buildings are already being printed using large-scale robots and cement-based printing pastes similar to mortar or concrete.  The vision to widely implement such technologies, however, is fraught with numerous technical hurdles including how to design the small-scale architectures that make-up the larger-scale structures and how to develop printing pastes that are reliable on any scale.  The work reported hear was part of a larger project between Tennessee Technological University (TTU), Vanderbilt University (VU) and Purdue University (PU) to investigate the effect of using controlled small-scale architectures to produce cement-based structures.  The TTU team’s goal was to identify ways to produce a reliable and scalable cement-based printing paste.  To this end, three integrated lines of inquiry were used: (1) a better understanding of how particles suspended in water flow, i.e. particulate suspensions, was developed, particularly focusing on particles of ordinary portland cement and particles that are physically similar and how off-the-shelf additives (“admixtures”) change their properties; (2) a new family of additives called hydrogels was investigated and the novel way that these water-loving materials might modify the flow properties of particulate suspension; and (3) a way to predict the flow behavior of particulate suspensions using mathematical descriptions call models was introduced.  It turns out that portland cement, and most fine particulate systems, exhibit complex flow behaviors when suspended in water.  The TTU team confirmed that when a layer of cement paste is sheared, like when the top layer of concrete is smoothed with a trowel, the cement becomes more fluid, this is called “shear thinning.”  And, if cement paste is sheared enough, it actually begins to resist more shearing, this is called “shear thickening.” Moreover, how much time is spent shearing the paste affects the observed behavior, a phenomena generally called “thixotropy.”  What the TTU team found is that the transition from shear thinning to shear thickening is affected by the addition of various admixtures.  This work should make it possible to identify admixture selection criteria to produce specific flow outcomes that benefit printing applications.  Moreover, most off-the-shelf admixtures were designed to make cement-based materials flow easier, i.e. to reduce the viscosity and the amount of force needed to make concrete flow.  Unfortunately, these two characteristics are not necessarily beneficial in printing applications.  The TTU team instead chose to consider alternative materials as new ways to form designer cement pastes with idealize properties for printing.  Using analogies from elsewhere, which seek to increase fluid viscosity and/or slipperiness, i.e. lubricity, the TTU team identified a family of polymers that are super water loving and transform water into a lubricating, viscous but very flowable mass called a “gel.”  Such polymers are used in food, pharmaceutical and cosmetic applications and include modified cellulose forms.  The team found that a readily available compound, hydroxy ethyl methyl cellulose (HEMC) is a very effective printing aid.  Addition of just over 1% by weight HEMC converts an otherwise unprintable cement-water mixture into a malleable, printable material.  Finally, engineers and scientists seek to find ways to predict material behavior using mathematical constructs inside of computers to save time and the expense of many experiments.  The TTU team has introduced a new approach to predict the outcomes of printing with cement-based materials.  They call the new concept, 2-Dimensional Stationary Computational Printing (2D-SCP).  The idea is simple.  Image you can only see what happens in a 2D plane.  When something enters the plane that remains, such as a printed layer of material, you would be able to observe how that something changes with time.  Now image you are watching the printing of a structure, but you only see a 2D slice as the structure is built.  You first see the first layer appear, after some time you see the second layer appear, and then the third and on-and-on.  During the time intervals between the appearance of a layer, however, you see how the previously deposited layers, that is the structure, changes.  This logic along with good estimates of the flow properties of the cement paste turns out to nicely predict the outcomes from actual printed 3-dimensional (3D) structures.  The team now better understands how cement pastes flow, how and why select off-the-shelf additives change the flow behavior, has identified a new family of hydrogel-forming polymers that transform otherwise unprintable cement pastes into robust printable materials and can also predict beforehand the shape of printed structures using mathematical constructs.

Modified by: Joseph J Biernacki

Images (1 of )
  • This figure shows a very nicely printed small cement cylinder printed with the help of a hydrogel-forming polymer called hydroxy ethyl methyl cellulose. Also listed are the three main thrust areas of the project.
    Hajar Taheri Afarani (TTU Graduate Student)
    Public Domain
    Joseph J Biernacki
    Figure 1
  • Comparison of actual printed object shape (cross-section) and computer generated (model) shape. This figure illustrates that the more malleable paste prints best but also that the computer model predicts the printed shape quite well. Scales are approximate.
    Abdul Salam Mohammad (TTU PhD Student)
    Public Domain
    Joseph J Biernacki
    Figure 2
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Additive manufacturing (AM), also called 3D printing, involves the layer-by-layer build-up of material to form an object, whereas subtractive manufacturing is the layer-by-layer removal of materials to form an object. In general, building layer-by-layer is less wasteful and provides greater design flexibility with respect to shapes that can be made. As incredible as it seems, houses and even commercial multi-story buildings are already being printed using large-scale robots and cement-based printing pastes similar to mortar or concrete. The vision to widely implement such technologies, however, is fraught with numerous technical hurdles including how to design the small-scale architectures that make-up the larger-scale structures and how to develop printing pastes that are reliable on any scale. The work reported hear was part of a larger project between Tennessee Technological University (TTU), Vanderbilt University (VU) and Purdue University (PU) to investigate the effect of using controlled small-scale architectures to produce cement-based structures. The TTU team’s goal was to identify ways to produce a reliable and scalable cement-based printing paste. To this end, three integrated lines of inquiry were used: (1) a better understanding of how particles suspended in water flow, i.e. particulate suspensions, was developed, particularly focusing on particles of ordinary portland cement and particles that are physically similar and how off-the-shelf additives ("admixtures") change their properties; (2) a new family of additives called hydrogels was investigated and the novel way that these water-loving materials might modify the flow properties of particulate suspension; and (3) a way to predict the flow behavior of particulate suspensions using mathematical descriptions call models was introduced. It turns out that portland cement, and most fine particulate systems, exhibit complex flow behaviors when suspended in water. The TTU team confirmed that when a layer of cement paste is sheared, like when the top layer of concrete is smoothed with a trowel, the cement becomes more fluid, this is called "shear thinning." And, if cement paste is sheared enough, it actually begins to resist more shearing, this is called "shear thickening." Moreover, how much time is spent shearing the paste affects the observed behavior, a phenomena generally called "thixotropy." What the TTU team found is that the transition from shear thinning to shear thickening is affected by the addition of various admixtures. This work should make it possible to identify admixture selection criteria to produce specific flow outcomes that benefit printing applications. Moreover, most off-the-shelf admixtures were designed to make cement-based materials flow easier, i.e. to reduce the viscosity and the amount of force needed to make concrete flow. Unfortunately, these two characteristics are not necessarily beneficial in printing applications. The TTU team instead chose to consider alternative materials as new ways to form designer cement pastes with idealize properties for printing. Using analogies from elsewhere, which seek to increase fluid viscosity and/or slipperiness, i.e. lubricity, the TTU team identified a family of polymers that are super water loving and transform water into a lubricating, viscous but very flowable mass called a "gel." Such polymers are used in food, pharmaceutical and cosmetic applications and include modified cellulose forms. The team found that a readily available compound, hydroxy ethyl methyl cellulose (HEMC) is a very effective printing aid. Addition of just over 1% by weight HEMC converts an otherwise unprintable cement-water mixture into a malleable, printable material. Finally, engineers and scientists seek to find ways to predict material behavior using mathematical constructs inside of computers to save time and the expense of many experiments. The TTU team has introduced a new approach to predict the outcomes of printing with cement-based materials. They call the new concept, 2-Dimensional Stationary Computational Printing (2D-SCP). The idea is simple. Image you can only see what happens in a 2D plane. When something enters the plane that remains, such as a printed layer of material, you would be able to observe how that something changes with time. Now image you are watching the printing of a structure, but you only see a 2D slice as the structure is built. You first see the first layer appear, after some time you see the second layer appear, and then the third and on-and-on. During the time intervals between the appearance of a layer, however, you see how the previously deposited layers, that is the structure, changes. This logic along with good estimates of the flow properties of the cement paste turns out to nicely predict the outcomes from actual printed 3-dimensional (3D) structures. The team now better understands how cement pastes flow, how and why select off-the-shelf additives change the flow behavior, has identified a new family of hydrogel-forming polymers that transform otherwise unprintable cement pastes into robust printable materials and can also predict beforehand the shape of printed structures using mathematical constructs.
